title: Tar Devils Sociology Symposium
text:
The symposium will take place at The Frank Porter Graham Student Union (Room 3206 AB) at UNC Chapel Hill.
Here is a parking map:

The union is highlighted in yellow.
Free parking can be found in the NG3 lots. From there, you can walk directly to the union.

title: Tar Devils Sociology Symposium
text:
Welcome to the Tar Devils Sociology Symposium webpage!
The second Tar Devils Sociology Symposium will be held February 7, 2026, at UNC Chapel Hill. It will bring together the graduate student researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Duke University.

title: Tar Devils Sociology Symposium
text:
9:45-10:00 REGISTRATION AND COFFEE
10:00-11:05 PANEL 1: IDENTITY AND BOUNDARY-MAKING
Discussant: Anna Shelton-Ormond
Imad Alatas. “‘I can say that I’m an extremely radical kind of feminist:’ Being a man in women’s rights spaces”
Braulio Güémez. “How Does Context Shape Ethnoracial Classification? The Case of the Indigenous Category in Mexico”
Jorge Mancilla. “Has Mexico’s Fertility Transition Played a Role in Abating Migration to the United States?”
11:15-12:00 FLASH TALKS 1
Discussant: Ben Rochford
Kaitlin Joshua. “Myths, guidelines, and best practices: How science and medicine shape the transition to parenthood”
Marty Kennedy. “Anti-Trans Bills, Cisgender Dominance: Examining Discursive Strategies in Support of Anti-Trans Legislation” Irene Lin. “From Plans to Realization: Fertility Outcomes and Gaps Among U.S. Women”
Zhe Chen. “Parental Sexism in Childhood and Women’s Cognitive Health Trajectories in Later Life: A Life-Course Analysis”
12:00-1:00 LUNCH
1:00 - 2:20 PANEL 2: POPULATION HEALTH INEQUALITIES
Discussant: Isabella Bouklas
Ariayana N. Harrell. “Persisting Health Implications of Structural Racism: Residential Segregation in Adolescence and Cardiometabolic Risk Among United States Black and White Adults”
Athena Owirodu. “Racial Disparities in Perceived Discrimination and Cardiovascular Kidney Metabolic Syndrome among U.S. Adults”
Erin L Cuellar Wright. “Trends in Hispanic Self-rated Health: Growth Curve Decomposition of Cohort, Age, and Period Effects across 15 Years of the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos (HCHS/SOL)”
Johannah Palomo. “Religiosity and Prenatal Distress: Insights from the Family Matters Study”
Onyekachukwu C. Arah. “Black Partners-Turned-Caregivers of Retired NFL Players Navigating Relationships, Identity, and Resources”
2:30 - 3:15 FLASH TALKS 2
Discussant: Andrew Joyce
Andrés Castro Araújo. “An Attention Model of Social Categorization” Katharina Klaunig. “Organizations as Destinations”
Natalia Fuentes-Rohwer. ““Expats” in Puerto Rico: Migration Experiences and Identity in an American Territory”
Chris Brehm. “Betting the House(hold): Population-level effects of mobile sports betting on marriage dissolution”
Kallan Larsen. “Relative Religiosity: A Case for Improved Measures”
3:15 - 3:30 COFFEE BREAK
3:30 - 4:50 PANEL 3: POLITICAL ECONOMY AND INSTITUTIONS
Discussant: Julia Murrow
Austin H. Vo. “Financing Under-Development: Agricultural Credit Societies and the turn to Anticolonialism in the French Empire”
Erica Janko. “Aging together: Community care as resistance to privatized elder care”
Ian Wallace. “Three Worlds of Welfare Autocracy?”
Xin (Louis) Zhao. “Not Just Filling Slots: International Medical Graduates and the Geographical Allocation of Medical Resources in the U.S.”
Yue Zhang. ““It’s Not Just the Hours”: Precarious Work and Gendered Organization of Household Labor Time”
5:00 HAPPY HOUR
